Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Political Connections and Firm Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
GENERAL SUMMARY

This project examines the effect of political connections on firm behavior. Both theory and previous research suggest that political connections confer greater profitability in such environments, but the extent to which such connections have real (as opposed to merely distributional) effects is an open question. To explore this question, the project utilizes a firm-level panel dataset that spans two periods of profound and largely unanticipated disruptions to political connections (the Orange Revolution in 2004 and the Euromaidan Revolution in 2013 and 2014. Contemporary Ukraine is the case of interest. Ukraine provides an environment in which there are weak political institutions and substantial oligarchic control of the economy. The results of this study will provide evidence on the channels through which political connections affect firms and will shed light on the real, as opposed to monetary, consequences of these connections.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project examines the effect of political connections on firm behavior and productivity, with an empirical focus on contemporary Ukraine. The research utilizes a firm-level panel dataset with many unusual variables (not just profitability, but also productivity, employment, wages, investment, R&D and IT investment, and energy inputs), supplemented with new data on oligarchic ownership. The data span two periods of profound and largely unanticipated disruptions to political connections the Orange Revolution in 2004 and the Euromaidan Revolution in 2013-14. Using new methods developed for this work and leveraging a natural experiment, the analysis will examine not only the direct effect of these shocks on connected firms, but also the indirect effects of spillovers on competitors (which may feed back to political outcomes) and on industry dynamics and productivity. The results of this study will provide evidence on the channels through which political connections affect firms and shed light on the consequences of these connections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examines the effect of political connections on firm behavior and performance. The research setting for this investigation is contemporary Ukraine, a country with weak legal and political institutions similar to those in much of the rest of the world. Both theory and previous research suggest that political connections may be more valuable in such environments, but the extent to which such connections have real (as opposed to merely distributional) effects is an open question.

The project utilizes a remarkable firm-level panel dataset that provides nearly universal coverage of Ukrainian enterprises from 1998 to 2013, with additional years to be added over the course of the project. A key component of the project, and a central justification for external support, is the collection of panel data on political connections to supplement other variables in the dataset. Together, these data allow for estimation of the channels through which political connections affect firms and the real, as opposed to monetary, consequences of those connections, with possible feedback to political outcomes.

In a first line of research, the project has analyzed firm-level ownership by oligarchs around the time of the 2004 Orange Revolution and studied the relationship of political connections with ?defensive ownership? arrangements, efforts to obfuscate" ownership through frontmen, related individuals, shell companies, and offshore firms. Prior to 2004, Ukrainian oligarchs were generally divided into two camps: "Blue," who supported the incumbent president and his chosen successor, Viktor Yanukovych, and "Orange," who supported the opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko. Combining information from investigative journalists with rich data on legal ownership ties, we identify the ownership chains of Blue and Orange oligarchs before and after the Orange Revolution. Our primary interest is the relationship between political connections (much stronger for Blue before the Orange Revolution, much stronger for Orange after) and various measures of obfuscation of ownership.

We develop a theoretical model of oligarch choices that implies, under some conditions, a negative relationship between connections and obfuscation, a pattern that is broadly evident in the data. Notably, we also observe a reversal of behavior following the Orange Revolution, as the value of Blue connections declined sharply with Yushchenko?s election victory. After 2004, previously connected ?Blue? oligarchs added foreign owners, including offshore vehicles, to obscure and protect their ownership. In an environment of generally poor protection of property rights, political connections and obfuscation of ownership can both secure property from predation. Our results clearly demonstrate the substitutability of these two mechanisms in postcommunist Ukraine around the time of the Orange Revolution. An interesting question for future research is whether we would observe similar patterns in countries with stronger properety rights and more frequent political turnover.

A second line of research has focused on the impact of privatization ? cutting ownership connections to the state ? on the performance of enterprises. Most oligarchs in Ukraine became wealthy through their acquisition of assets through privatization (although this was not the only channel), so understanding the process of privatization and its consequences is an important component of the overall project. It is also essential for analyzing the behavior of the state sector, where asset stripping has also been a channel for oligarch enrichment.

The results from this analysis include an updating of previous results by the authors. As shown in the accompanying figure, we estimate that majority privatization raises multi-factor productivity (MFP) 4-10%, with the impact increasing over time to about 16-18% six years after privatization, which exceed those from previous research on Ukraine and lie in the general range of estimates for Central Europe. Privatization also raises aggregate productivity through a stronger survival-productivity linkage. Foreign takeovers are associated with much higher impacts, 17-33%, except when the foreign source country is a tax haven or Russia.

Another related line of work has focused on foreign direct investment (FDI), particularly from tax havens, often used by oligarchs to obscure ownership. The focus here is on the firm performance effects of FDI from different source countries. Finally, the project contributes an analysis of Ukraine to a cross-country comparative study of productivity dispersion and misallocation.
